misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sc.next() is a specialized instruction that reads a 'name' (as a complete semantic unit) because it follows a prompt asking for names.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student is treating the Scanner's input method as context-aware and anthropomorphic. In reality, Java's Scanner.next() is a technical delimiter-based tool that only reads until the next whitespace, regardless of the prompt's intent or the human concept of a 'full name'.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: If a user enters a name containing a space (e.g., 'Alice Smith'), the program will read 'Alice' as the first name and 'Smith' as the second name, leading to index errors or an InputMismatchException when the loop for integers begins.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the input stream is logically partitioned by the output prompts, meaning all tokens typed after the 'Enter names' prompt are categorized as Strings and all tokens typed after 'Enter scores' are categorized as integers.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student sees the input stream as having a 'state' dictated by the preceding print statement. However, the Java Notional Machine treats System.in as a single continuous stream of tokens; the prompts have no functional effect on how Scanner methods interpret the buffer.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: This belief manifests in the use of two separate loops (one for names, one for scores) that assume the user will enter all names followed by all scores, which would fail if the user attempted to enter data student-by-student (name, then score).

evidence.code_snippet: for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) { names[i] = sc.next(); }
for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) { scores_array[i] = sc.nextInt(); }
